official-title.#text:
To prohibit the Secretary of Labor from enforcing any
		  requirement that consumer reporting agencies that serve only as a secure
		  conduit to data from State unemployment compensation agencies obtain and
		  maintain an individual’s informed consent agreement when verifying income and
		  employment with such agencies, and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced
			 the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Ability to Repay Verification Enabling
			 Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

Economic growth
			 requires access to affordable credit which depends on consumers’ ability to
			 understand the terms of any loans they make and the ability of lenders to have
			 an understanding of the consumers’ ability and willingness to repay
			 loans.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
require lenders to ascertain borrowers’ willingness and ability to
			 repay prior to making a loan.

text.#text:
Lenders and
			 consumers receive benefits such as quicker approval, lower interest rates,
			 protection of privacy, and stronger anti-fraud protections from automatic
			 underwriting utilizing existing databases.

Eleven States (Alabama, California,
			 Florida, Georgia, Indiana, Louisiana, Missouri, New York, Ohio, Oregon, and
			 Virginia) passed enabling legislation or rules enabling consumers who request
			 that third parties using consumer report information for purposes of
			 eligibility determination have efficient access to this information from the
			 State’s unemployment insurance database.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
requirements
			 already require third parties using consumer report information for purposes of
			 eligibility determination to obtain and maintain consent agreements.

text.#text:
Notwithstanding any other provision of law,
			 the

header.#text:
Prohibition on
			 requirement for onward transfer of consent agreements

text.#text:
take any action to implement or enforce the
			 requirement described in the Unemployment Insurance Program Letter No. 19–12,
			 dated May 23, 2012, that a third-party consumer reporting agency that serves
			 only as a secure conduit to data from State unemployment compensation agencies
			 and that is not an agent of an individual obtain and maintain an informed
			 consent agreement from such individual if the third-party consumer reporting
			 agency seeks to obtain confidential unemployment compensation information with
			 respect to such individual from a State; or

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Ability to Repay Verification Enabling Act/s:3/p:1

text.#text:
issue, implement, administer, or enforce
			 any rule or other guidance that is the same as, or similar in effect to, the
			 requirement described in

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HR 2722 IH: Ability to Repay Verification Enabling Act
